subject: Legacy keyboard mapping
msgSnippet: Andy, I have questioned the keyboard map used for Shavian and Quickscript. You can get used to anything but the current keyboard for the Read scripts seems to
messageBody:
Andy,

I have questioned the keyboard map used for Shavian and Quickscript.
You can get used to anything but the current keyboard for the Read
scripts seems to make that more challenging to the novice than it
needs to be.

There are hundreds of possible phonemic keyboard mappings.
It is unfortunate that the first font did not used one of the more
popular ones such as SAMPA [Univ. of London Linguistics Dept].

I also like the scheme used at www.m-w.com and the closely related
Unifon. see www.foolswisdom.com/~sbett/shaw-short.htm

--- Andii Bowsher wrote:

READ: fFndN H rFt kIz f H les dFrektli mApabl kAraktDz iz not IzI, iz
it? nId t mEk a kIbR mAp.

Mistakes? kIbR = kIbärd, f for av/uv

UNIFON: fIndN D rIt kEz v D les dIrektlE mapcbl karktcrz iz not EzE,
iz it? nEd tU mAk c kEbOrd map.

I think that English speaking novices would find keyboard Unifon
easier to read. Details: www.unifon.org


j-fo@... wrote:

TANks gFz, tMk mI a wFl t wxk i Qt bat F got HEr in H end. READSCRIPT
Errors? tVk but Her
TaNks gIz, tUk mE c wYl tU wurk it qt but I got Der in D end. UNIFON
TqNks gYz, tvk mE a wYl tw wRk it qvt but Y got Der in D end. ENgliS

--Steve
